questions.uddipok:
Read the following beginning of a story and develop it into a complete story. Give a suitable title to your story (in around 200 words).
Once upon a time, there was a pond full of frogs. As it was during the rainy season, it was filled to brim with water. Many frogs took their shelter in the pond......

sub_questions.explanation:
The Proud Frog and the Pond
Once upon a time, there was a pond full of frogs. As it was during the rainy season, it was filled to the brim with water. Many frogs took shelter in the pond, jumping, playing, and croaking all day long. The pond was lively and cheerful.
Among them was a proud frog who believed he was the biggest and strongest of all. He would often boast about his strength and size to the other frogs, claiming that he could defeat any creature that came near the pond.
One day, a group of travelers passed by the pond with a large ox. The frogs curiously peeked from the water to see the huge animal. The proud frog, seeing the ox, felt his pride hurt. “That creature may be big,” he said loudly, “but I can be just as big if I want to!”
He began puffing himself up. “Look! Am I as big as that ox now?” he asked the other frogs.
“No, not yet,” replied the frogs.
The proud frog puffed himself up even more. “Now?”
“Still not as big,” they said.
Angry and determined, the proud frog puffed and puffed, trying to become as large as the ox. But in his foolish attempt, he puffed so much that his body couldn’t handle it. With a loud pop! , he burst and died on the spot.
All the other frogs were shocked and saddened. They had tried to warn him, but his pride had made him blind to reason.
Moral: Pride and envy can lead to one's downfall. Be content with who you are and never try to be someone you're not.

questions.uddipok: Write a letter to your younger brother/sister advising him/her not to share fake or baseless news on his/her social media account.

sub_questions.explanation:
Subject: Importance of Responsible Social Media Sharing
Dear [Younger Brother/Sister's Name],
I hope this letter finds you well. As your older sibling, I feel it's important to share some advice regarding your social media activities, particularly concerning the sharing of news articles and information.
In today's digital age, social media has become a powerful tool for communication and information sharing. While it offers numerous benefits, it also comes with certain responsibilities. One of these responsibilities is ensuring that the information we share is accurate, reliable, and credible.
I've noticed that lately, you've been sharing a lot of news articles and stories on your social media accounts without verifying their authenticity. While I understand the urge to stay informed and share interesting content with your friends and followers, it's crucial to remember that not everything you come across on the internet is true.
Sharing fake or baseless news can have serious consequences. Not only does it contribute to the spread of misinformation, but it can also harm the reputations of individuals and organizations unfairly targeted by false claims. Moreover, it can fuel unnecessary panic and confusion among people who may believe the misinformation to be true.
Before sharing any news article or story on your social media accounts, I urge you to take a moment to verify its credibility. Look for reliable sources, cross-check the information with other reputable news outlets, and consider the context in which the story is presented. If you're unsure about the accuracy of a particular piece of news, it's better to refrain from sharing it altogether.
Remember that as a member of the online community, you have the power to influence others with the content you share. By being mindful of the information you share and prioritizing accuracy and credibility, you can contribute to a more informed and responsible digital environment.
If you ever come across news or information that you're unsure about, don't hesitate to reach out to me or other trusted sources for guidance. Together, we can work towards promoting responsible social media behavior and combating the spread of misinformation.
Thank you for taking the time to read this letter, and please know that I'm always here to offer support and guidance whenever you need it.
Take care, and I look forward to seeing you soon.
Warm regards,
[Your Name]

questions.uddipok:
Read the following text and make a flow-chart showing the major features of the Island of St. Martin. (One has been done for you):
The Island of St. Martin is the only coral island in Bangladesh located in the north-eastern part of Bay of Bengal. The roughly flat island is only above 3.6 metre above the sea level. The entire island can be walked about in 3 hours. The island is known for its unique natural beauty with white sandy beaches fringed with coconut palms and a diverse marine life. Due to the expansion of unregulated tourism, the island is facing increasing erosion, contamination of surface and ground water, wildlife displacement, and loss of biodiversity. Other threats include cutting of sand dune vegetation for fuel-wood and hotel establishment; degradation of sand dune habitat; the harvesting of turtle eggs; indiscriminate exploitation of coral resources etc. To address this, the Government has declared some areas of the island as Ecologically Critical Area (ECA), prohibiting unauthorized constructions there.

questions.uddipok:
QuestionRearrange the following sentences to make a coherent order.
(i) But first he wanted to know how much they loved him.
(ii) Lear was shocked and said, "Nothing will come of nothing"..
(iii) At first he asked his eldest daughter, "How much do you love me?"
(iv) Goneril declared, "Sir, I love you more than I can say." (v) Lear was pleased and gave her one-third of his kingdom.
(vi) Being satisfied, Lear called for the map of his kingdom and drew his finger round one third of it. (vii) When asked, his second daughter Regan said, "My love for you shall never change."
(viii) He made up his mind to step down from the throne and divide his kingdom.
(ix) When asked his youngest and most beloved daughter Cordelia, said, "Nothing".
(x) Long long ago there lived a mighty king of England named Lear who had three daughters - Goneril, Regan and Cordelia.

sub_questions.explanation:
(x) →(viii) →(i)→ (iii) →(iv)→(vi) → (vii)→(v)→(ix) → (ii)
Long long ago there lived a mighty old king of England named Lear who had three daughters- Goneril, Regan and Cordelia. He made up his mind to step down from the throne and divide his kingdom. But first, he wanted to know how much they loved him. At first he asked his eldest daughter, "How much do you love me?" Goneril declared, "Sir, I love you more than I can say." Being satisfied, Lear called for the map of his kingdom and drew his finger round one-third of it. When asked, his second daughter Regan said, "My love for you shall never change." Lear was pleased and gave her one-third of his kingdom. When asked the youngest and most beloved daughter Cordelia, said, "Nothing". Lear was shocked and said, "Nothing will come of nothing."
